person.note: Biblical prophet. Older brother of Moses and son of Abraham.
Arab trader.
Arab trader.
Arab trader, and one of the first Arab settlers in Nyangwe. Assisted Livingstone's travels; produced the Zingifure ink with which Livingstone wrote the 1871 Field Diary.
One of three Biblical patriarchs.
One of a group of men from a government-run school for freed slaves in Nashik (spelled "Nassick" by Livingstone), India who accompanied Livingstone on his last journey.
Third son of David, the king of Israel, in the Old Testament.
In Greek mythology, hero of the Trojan war and a main character of Homer's Iliad.

Author of Dr. Livingston [sic]: His Life and Adventures in the Interior of South Africa (1857), a book based on Livingstone's letters regarding his transcontinental African journey. Also wrote David Livingstone: The Weaver Boy who Became a Missionary (1874).
Arab trader.
African who assisted Livingstone on the Zambesi expedition, was taken to India, then returned with Livingstone for the final expedition.
Arab trader originally from Muscat.

George Douglas Campbell. Succeeded to the title in 1847. A Liberal. Held several Government posts. The First Gladstone Ministry (1868-74) came into power in December 1868, with Argyll as the Secretary of State for India.

Cartographer and map publisher. Founding fellow of the Royal Geographical Society in 1830 and member of the Society's council from 1851 to 1868. His interest in exploration and discovery coupled with his skill in converting rough sketch maps of explorers into professionally published maps led to a significant body of cartographical contributions to the Society's publications.
Arab trader, dispatched with Shereef Bosher from the coast in 1869 by Ludha Damji, "the richest Banian in Zanzibar," to supply Livingstone with goods and men.

Appointed artist-storekeeper to the Zambesi Expedition. Dismissed by Livingstone for the misuse of government property. Journeyed to Victoria Falls with James Chapman. Published first paintings of the Falls in 1865.

Explorer. Born in the Austrian Empire, she was purchased at a Bulgarian slave market by her future husband Samuel W. Baker in 1859. In 1864, she and Samuel became the first Europeans to visit present-day Lake Albert, one of the most important central African lakes.

Explorer and hunter. In 1864, he and his wife Florence Baker became the first Europeans to visit present-day Lake Albert, one of the most important central African lakes. On a subsequent expedition to the region (1869-73), served as Governor-General of the Equatorial Nile Basin.
Individual based in Natal, who found the missionary Holloway Helmore and his family in the desert en route to Linyanti in 1859 and assisted them.

Reference uncertain. Bessie Bell and Mary Gray are the heroines of an eponymous Scottish ballad collected in English and Scottish Ballads (1860), a well-known anthology created by Francis James Child.
Arab trader.
Arab trader.

Apparently an agent of the P & O Company (Peninsular and Oriental Steam Navigation Company), a British shipping company. This may be the "W. Black" to whom Livingstone wrote a letter on 15 November 1871.
German philologist who specialized in South African languages. Settled in Cape Town in 1856 and was appointed by Sir George Grey as interpreter in 1857 and librarian of his collection in 1860.
Also Napoleon III. President (r.1848–52) of the French Second Republic and Emperor (1852–70) of the Second French Empire.

Arab trader. Dispatched from the coast in 1869 by Ludha Damji, a very rich Banian from Zanzibar, to supply Livingstone with goods and men, then spent fourteen months on the journey to Ujiji, while systematically plundering Livingstone of his goods.
Barrister and member of the Society of Friends whom Livingstone met in 1857 and corresponded with for the rest of his life. Was a friend of the Moffats, Livingstone's in-laws.
Arab trader.
Politician. The First Gladstone Ministry (1868-74) came into power in December 1868 with John Bright serving as the President of the Board of Trade.

Explorer, writer, translator. Made a famous expedition to Mecca in disguise in 1853. Led an expedition (1856-59) that resulted in the first sighting of Lake Tanganyika by Europeans. However, John H. Speke's discovery of Lake Victoria, the source of the Nile, on that same expedition led to a bitter public dispute that ultimately derailed the overall trajectory of Burton's later career.
One of the "ringleaders" of a rebellious group of liberated Banian slaves hired by John Kirk, the acting British Consul and Political Resident at Zanzibar, to assist Livingstone.
African chief.
African chief.
African chief.
African chief.
Member of the Yao tribe and freed slave. Travelled with Livingstone until the latter's death, then accompanied Livingstone's body back to Britain where he helped edit the Last Journals (1874).
African chief.

George William Frederick Villiers. Foreign Secretary 1853-58, 1865-66, and 1868-70. Involved in both Livingstone's Zambesi and final expeditions. Livingstone gave his name to Mount Clarendon, east of the Shire River.

Geographer and founder of the Hakluyt Society. Early work on mapping the African interior (via classical sources and contemporary accounts) built his reputation as a geographical authority. Later critiques of explorers transformed him into one of the most notorious "armchair geographers" of his day.
French explorer and geographer. With Louis Sabatier and Ferdinand Werne, navigated the White Nile to 4° 42' in 1841.
African chief.

Wealthy Banian customs collector and slave trader based in Zanzibar. Livingstone blamed him for supplying all the guns and gunpowder of Tagamoio, the chief perpetrator of the massacre at Nyangwe in 1871.
Maltese explorer. Known for his exploration of the sources of the White Nile.
Also Molembalemba. Arab trader. His followers were the main instigators of the Nyangwe massacre in 1871.

Colonial administrator. Entered the Bombay Civil Service in 1834. Went to Zanzibar in 1872 to negotiate the suppression of the slave trade. Governor of Bombay 1862-67. President of Royal Geographical Society 1873-74.
African of the Nyamwezi tribe.
Also Kimamure. African chief. Descendant of Charura. Son of Moenyegumbe.

One of a group of men from a government-run school for freed slaves in Nashik (spelled "Nassick" by Livingstone), India who accompanied Livingstone on his last journey. Later also accompanied Henry M. Stanley.
One of Livingstone's porters.
African person.
Officer in the Indian Army. Was seconded to John H. Speke's second African expedition, 1860-63, which sought to confirm the source of the Nile.

Reference uncertain. Bessie Bell and Mary Gray are the heroines of an eponymous Scottish ballad collected in English and Scottish Ballads (1860), a well-known anthology created by Francis James Child.
African trader.
One of Noah's three sons in the Old Testament.

Minister of Regent Square Presbyterian Church, London 1841-67. Editor of Evangelical Christendom 1864-67. Livingstone attended his church and stayed at his house in 1865, and contributed a paper to his periodical.
Arab trader, and one of the first Arab settlers in Nyangwe. Known locally in Nyangwe for his violence and suspected by Livingstone of stirring up the latter's Banian slaves to rebellion.

Missionary. Sent with his family by the London Missionary Society at the behest of Livingstone to settle among the Kololo at Linyanti (in present-day Namibia), where he and much of his family died in 1860. Livingstone grieved at the deaths and, indeed, in some quarters was held responsible.
Ancient Greek traveler and historian, known for his History, which chronicles the origins of the Greco-Persian wars.
Celebrated surgeon and anatomist, whose collection of medical specimens became the basis of the eponymous Hunterian Museum.
One of a group of men from a government-run school for freed slaves in Nashik (spelled "Nassick" by Livingstone), India who accompanied Livingstone on his last journey.
Biblical prophet, documented in the Book of Isaiah.
African chief.
Also Ishmael. Khedive of Egypt and Sudan (r.1863-79). Oversaw building of Egyptian portion of Suez Canal.
One of Livingstone's porters, killed in February 1871.
Arab trader.
Jesus Christ or Jesus of Nazareth. The central figure of Christianity.
Also Reuel. Father-in-law of Moses in the Bible.
Cartographer, engineer, and archaeologist. Under Napoleon, edited the monumental Description of Egypt (1809-29).
Arab trader.
Master of Balliol College, University of Oxford.
One of the "ringleaders" of a rebellious group of liberated Banian slaves hired by John Kirk, the acting British Consul and Political Resident at Zanzibar, to assist Livingstone.
African person.
African chief.

Also Karenga. African chief of an unknown village near Nyangwe, possibly of the Bagenya people. Livingstone failed to negotiate with Kalenga for the purchase of a canoe in May and June 1871, and ultimately sent his followers to flog Kalenga although the latter fled.

One of the freed Banian slaves hired by John Kirk, the acting British Consul and Political Resident at Zanzibar, to transport goods for Livingstone. Detained by Syde bin Salem Burashid, the governor ("Lewale") or trade agent of Unyanyembe, so the goods could be plundered by Musa bin Salem, the governor's slave.
African chief.
African chief; brother of Moenekuss, chief of Bambarre.
Member of the Bagenya tribe under Kimburu.
African chief.

Chief of a strategically important African village near the Lualaba River. During the period in question, developed friendly relations with Arab traders and began to employ Arab methods of violence against other local African populations.
African chief.
Also known as Moenemokaia. Arab trader based at Mamohela. Brother of Moeneghere.
African chief.

Chief of the Balunda (r. 1862-68), whom Livingstone visited at the former's capital Kanyembo (in present-day northern Zambia) in 1867 and again in 1868. On the latter visit, the chief provided Livingstone with key geographical information about the Congo river system.
Abraham's concubine in the Bible.
Also Chimburu. African chief of the Bagenya people. His attempt to form an alliance with Manilla, an African slave, helped incite the Nyangwe massacre.
George William Fox Kinnaird. Agricultural reformer and philanthropist, concerned with the conditions of laborers.

Doctor, naturalist, political agent. Served as Livingstone's chief assistant during the Zambesi Expedition. Appointed Surgeon to the British Agency in Zanzibar in 1865. During the period in question, was acting Consul and Political Resident at Zanzibar
African chief.
Lazarus of Bethany (brother of Martha and Mary). Said to be raised from the dead by Jesus in the Gospel of John.

person.persName: Linant de Bellefonds, Louis Maurice Adolphe
person.note: Explorer and chief engineer of the Suez Canal. In 1827, traveled up the White Nile to about 13° N.
Sixteenth president of the United States. Known for abolishing slavery in the U.S. by signing the Emancipation Proclamation.

Eldest daughter of David Livingstone. Went to England with her mother in 1852, accompanied her father in 1864-65. Was one of Livingstone's most engaged correspondents and transcribed some of his manuscripts, including the 1870 Field Diary.
Brother of David Livingstone. Educated at Oberlin College, Ohio 1840-47, and Union Theological Seminary, New York 1847-49. David's assistant on the Zambesi Expedition.
Famous Victorian explorer, missionary, and abolitionist. Renowned for his travels across Africa and extensive manuscript corpus.
Brother of David Livingstone. Emigrated to Canada, where after some years he settled as a farmer at Listowel, Ontario.
Second son of David Livingstone. Went to England with his mother in 1852. Lived in Egypt for the benefit of his health.
African headman of the Malobo tribe.
American Romantic poet, associated with the Fireside Poets. Interested in poetry as a vehicle of reform, particularly for the cause of abolition.
African chief.
Chief of the Bahika tribe.
German theologian of the fifteenth and sixteenth centuries and a key figure of the Protestant Reformation.

Chosen to lead the Universities' Mission to Central Africa. Consecrated Bishop of Central Africa in Cape Town 1861. Died in 1862 of fever at the confluence of the Ruo and Shire Rivers. In some quarters, Livingstone was held responsible for his death.

Astronomer of the Royal Observatory at Cape Town. Met Livingstone in 1852, became a close friend. Thereafter Livingstone depended on him to check his observations. Livingstone named Cape Maclear after him.

Son of Said ibn Sultan, the first Omani ruler of Zanzibar, and himself Sultan of Zanzibar 1856-70. Helped develop a far-ranging empire in East Africa, including a well-developed slave trading network.
African person.
Reference uncertain. Possibly a Banian customs collector and/or slave trader.
African chief.
African chief.

Slave of Syde bin Habib, a well known Arab trader whom Livingstone had met at Linyati in 1853 and again in 1868-69 in Central Africa. The Arabs of Nyangwe claimed to have started the Nyangwe massacre as retaliation for Manilla's efforts to form an alliance with Chimburu, an African chief residing near Nyangwe.
One of a group of men from a government-run school for freed slaves in Nashik (spelled "Nassick" by Livingstone), India who accompanied Livingstone on his last journey.
Martha of Bethany (sister of Lazarus and Mary). Witness to Lazarus's resurrection by Jesus in the Gospel of John.
Mary of Bethany (sister of Lazarus and Martha). Witness to Lazarus's resurrection by Jesus in the Gospel of John.
African chief.
One of Livingstone's porters.
The paramount chief of the Lunda kingdom.
Arab trader based in Kasongo.
Arab trader.
Surgeon of the "Pioneer." Served in the Zambesi region 1861-63. Was Vice-Consul in Madagascar 1865-66, and was associated with botanical gardens in Mauritius and Queensland.
Also Mamerere. African chief who resisted Arab encroachment into central Africa. Descendant of Charura.
Arab trader.
Foster-mother of Moses in the Bible.
Herdsman and child of Abraham and Keturah in the Bible.

Ancient goddess whom the Romans equated with the Greek goddess Athena. Her secretary (or scribe) met the ancient Greek historian Herodotus in the city of Sais and provided the latter with a variety of geographical details related to the source of the Nile.
Older sister of Moses and Aaron in the Bible.
African chief.
African chief.
Arab trader. Brother of Moenemokaia (a.k.a. Katomba).
African chief.
Chief of Bambarre and, according to Livingstone, the most influential chief in the Manyema region.
Older son of Moenekuss, chief of Bambarre.
Younger son of Moenekuss; chief of Bambarre when Livingstone composed the 1870 Field Diary.
Chief of Luamo; married to sister of Moenekuss, chief of Bambarre.
African chief.
African chief.
African chief.
African chief.
Arab trader.
Arab trader.
Arab trader.
African chief. Descendant of Charura. Father of Garahenga Mogandira.
African chief.
African chief. Descendant of Charura. Son of Moenyegumbe. Died after one year of rule.
Arab trader.
Also Mokandirwa and Moene Lualaba. African chief of Nyangwe.
African chief. Descendant of Charura.
African person.
African chief.
African chief.
African person.
African chief.
Biblical prophet. Brother of Aaron and son of Abraham.
African chief whom Livingstone attempt to convert during his earliest efforts as a missionary.
African chief.
African chief of the Ñoñgo.
African chief.
Prophet and founder of Islam.
Vizier ("Wuzeer") of Zanzibar.
Arab trader based at Ujiji who assisted Livingstone in his travels.

Liberated Swahili slave turned trader, with whom Livingstone had previously travelled in 1867-68. Although known locally in Central Africa for the violence of his followers, Bogharib assisted Livingstone and treated him kindly.
African chief.
African chief.
Geologist. Wife and intellectual partner of Roderick Murchison, geologist and president of the Royal Geographical Society.
Famous geologist and president of the Royal Geographical Society 1843-45, 1851-53, 1856-59 and 1862-71. Met Livingstone in 1856, and they became close friends.

Foreign Office official. Drew up a set of instructions dated 28 March 1865 and signed by Lord John Russell that denied Livingstone a salary and pension for his honorary consulship. Livingstone found the wording of the instructions offensive, carried a grudge to the end of his life, and held Murray responsible.
Son of the founder of John Murray, Publisher. Was Livingstone's publisher and adviser.
Leader of a group of ten men from Johanna (Anjouan), Comoros, who accompanied Livingstone during his last journey.
Baluchi slave of Syde bin Salem Burashid, the governor ("Lewale") or trade agent of Unyanyembe. Apparently defrauded Livingstone of some portion of goods sent from the coast.
Ruler of Buganda (r.1857-84). During his second expedition to Africa (1860-63), John H. Speke stayed at Mutesa’s court from early to mid 1862.
African chief.
Nero Caesar Augustus. Fifth emperor of the Roman empire.
African chief.
Explorer and hunter. Met Livingstone in South Africa in 1845, and travelled with him 1849-51. Remained close friends.

Anatomist and naturalist. Taught Livingstone in 1840. Conservator of the Hunterian Museum at the Royal College of Surgeons of England 1827-56. Professor of Comparative Anatomy and Physiology 1836-56. Superintendent of the British Museum 1856-83. Knighted 1884.
Henry John Temple. Foreign Secretary 1830-41, 1846-51. Prime Minister 1859-65. Livingstone was in agreement with his anti-slavery policies.
Classical Greek philosopher. Pupil of Socrates.
Lieutenant Colonel in the Madras army. Consul at Zanzibar, and for Algeria 1867-96. Knighted 1886.
African of the Nyamwezi tribe.
One of a group of men from a government-run school for freed slaves in Nashik (spelled "Nassick" by Livingstone), India who accompanied Livingstone on his last journey.
Greco-Egyptian writer and geographer; Livingstone depended on his information about the source of the Nile.
Church of England clergyman and theologian.
African chief of the Bagenya tribe. Related to Kimburu (a.k.a. Chimburu), whose actions helped incite the Nyangwe massacre.
Appointed engineer to the Zambesi Expedition in February 1858, until 1864. Went into business in Zanzibar, but died prematurely in Glasgow a year later.
Arab trader.
Arab trader.
Traveller and novelist. Known in the 1860s for his travels in West Africa.
Also Jethro. Father-in-law of Moses in the Bible.
Member of Parliament and leader of the Whigs. Created Earl Russell 1861.
French explorer. With Joseph-Pons d'Arnauld and Ferdinand Werne, navigated the White Nile to 4° 42' in 1841.
One of Livingstone's porters.
Arab trader.
First king of the united kingdom of Israel and Judah in the Hebrew bible.

Leader of the Kololo. Displaced with the Kololo from southern Africa during the Mfecane in the 1820s, eventually settling in the Zambezi Valley in the 1840s where the Kololo conquered the local Lozi. Died shortly after meeting Livingstone in 1851, when the Kololo state was at the height of its power.

Leader of the Bakwena. Built power and prestige by trading with visiting Europeans and extending trading routes. Converted to Christianity soon after Livingstone arrived among the Bakwena in 1846. Became an important figure in the Christianisation of southern Africa. Also instrumental in the formation of the Bechuanaland Protectorate and in contesting the efforts of Transvaal Boers to appropriate his lands.
Individual whom the ancient Greek traveler and historian Herodotus visited in the city of Sais and who provided Herodotus with a variety of geographical details related to the source of the Nile.

Chief of the Kololo, son of Sebituane. Supported Livingstone’s transcontinental expedition (1852-56) in the hope of extending his trade routes and authority. A London Missionary Society mission to the Kololo in the 1860s resulted in the majority of the members dying from fever, with Sekeletu wrongly suspected of having poisoned the party.
Assistant Surgeon in the Bombay establishment 1855. Served as Agency Surgeon, Acting Political Agent, and Acting Consul in Zanzibar, where Livingstone met him in 1864. Retired in 1884.
Arab governor ("Lewale") of Zanzibar.
Arab trader.
Arab trader.
Portuguese Commandant of Tete up to 1859. Commandant of Mazaro and the Shire 1862-64. Temporary Governor of Quilimane.
One of a group of men from a government-run school for freed slaves in Nashik (spelled "Nassick" by Livingstone), India who accompanied Livingstone on his last journey.
Biblical King of Israel and son of David.

Explorer. In 1858, became the first European to visit present-day Lake Victoria, which he claimed (correctly), but could not prove was the mythical source of the Nile. Led a second expedition to the lake in 1860-63, which also failed to establish his claim definitively. Died on the eve of major public debate with his rival Richard F. Burton.
Author of the book of Revelation in the Bible.
Fifth-century Christian missionary in Ireland. Primary patron saint of Ireland.
Apostle of the New Testament and one of the main proponents of early Christianity.
First martyr of Christianity. Mentioned in the Acts of the Apostles in the New Testament.
Edward Henry Stanley. Succeeded as 15th Earl of Derby in 1869. Conservative politician, inter alia Foreign Secretary 1866-68.
Merchant from Massachusetts. Partner of Stearns, Hobart and Co. in Bombay 1857-68. Livingstone met him on board ship in 1865 and lived in his house for much of his stay in Bombay.
Abolitionist and author best known for Uncle Tom's Cabin (1852).
Arab trader.
Arab person.
Ruler of Buganda (r. 1832-1856).
Also Zurampela. African chief from an unknown village near Loeki River.

African of the Shupanga tribe. Travelled with Livingstone until the latter's death, then accompanied Livingstone's body back to Britain where he helped edit the Last Journals (1874). Spoke good English and provided Horace Waller with a narrative of Livingstone's last days.
Arab trader.

Arab trader, who traveled widely in central Africa. Livingstone first encountered him in 1855 during the former's famous transcontinental African journey and again during his (Livingstone's) last journey.

Arab governor ("Lewale") or trade agent of Unyanyembe, who apparently detained and/or destroyed a packet of letters Livingstone had tried to send to the coast and also prevented other goods from reaching Livingstone in Manyema.
Arab trader.
Surgeon. Highly regarded as a practitioner and teacher of surgery. President of the Royal College of Surgeons of Edinburgh 1849-51.

Also Mtagamoyo or Mwini Mohara. Arab trader and the chief perpetrator of the Nyangwe massacre. Tagamoio would eventually become one of the leading Arabs at Nyangwe and would only be brought down and killed by Belgian forces in 1893 (Wissman 1890:176-95; Hinde 1895:433).
Arab trader based in Ujiji.

Explorer. Ascended the White Nile to Gondokoro in 1862, then traveled along the Bahr el Ghazal, the principal western tributary of the Nile. Killed in 1869 during an expedition across the Sahara Desert.
Renowned central African ivory and slave trader.
Also Taharqa, Taharka, or Tirhakah. Pharaoh of the twenty-fifth dynasty in ancient Egypt (r.690-664 BC) and king of the kingdom of Kush.

Biblical scholar and Irish historian. Wrote St. Patrick, Apostle of Ireland: A Memoir of His Life and Mission (1864). On his last journey, Livingstone had with him a review of this book published in the Quarterly Review (1866) and used the page margins of this review to construct the first gathering of the 1870 Field Diary.
Bishop of Universities' Mission to Central Africa 1862-63, Zanzibar 1863-73, Jamaica 1879-80, and Honduras 1880-81. Livingstone never forgave him for moving the UMCA to Zanzibar in 1862-63.
Resident of Bombay with whom Livingstone stayed in 1865.
German explorer. In 1861 became the first European to attempt an ascent of Mount Kilimanjaro. Murdered on a subsequent expedition in the area of present-day Bardera, Somalia.

Lay Superintendent, Universities' Mission to Central Africa 1860-64. Curate, St. John's Chatham 1867-70. Vicar of Leytonstone, 1870-74. Rector of Twywell, 1874-95. In addition to editing Livingstone's Last Journals, wrote several articles on slavery and the slave trade in Africa.
Big-game hunter whom Livingstone and his son Oswell met in 1850. Livingstone stayed at his house, Newstead Abbey in Nottinghamshire, in 1864-65.
Slave of Arab trader Thani bin Suellim.
Scottish industrialist who made a fortune distilling paraffin from shale. Met Livingstone at Anderson's College. Was one of Livingstone's three trustees.
African headman of the Malobo tribe.
Warrior from Cush (present-day Ethiopia) mentioned in the Book of Chronicles.
